repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
As you might know, cygdb is currently in an unusable state.
Many tests that can be executed by running `python TestLibCython.py` don't pass.

The "cy print"  command was broken, so I replaced it with this code:
`self.cy.exec_.invoke("print(" + name + ")", from_tty)`
The main advantage of this code is that it reduces the complexity and code size of Cygdb.
Another advantage is that it can use `__repr__` functions and is therefore consistent with pdb.
The disadvantage is that `cy print *var` no longer works, but I think you should use `cy_cname` and gdb's `print` function instead. I'm going to update the documentation about this.
This was when I found out that `cy exec` is also broken, it can't read local variables.
This bug is the only thing seperating a nearly unusable cygdb from a cygdb that passes all tests.

Fixing this bug is beyond my Cython-knowledge, so I will ask on the mailing list with additional details about this bug.

comment_data.body: Any idea if that changed at some point? I mean, this test probably worked initially, when it was written.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -177,12 +177,13 @@ def test_break_lineno(self):
         assert step_result.rstrip().endswith(nextline)
 
 
-class TestKilled(DebugTestCase):
-
-    def test_abort(self):
-        gdb.execute("set args -c 'import os; os.abort()'")
-        output = gdb.execute('cy run', to_string=True)
-        assert 'abort' in output.lower()
+# I removed this testcase, because it will never work, because
+# gdb.execute(..., to_string=True) does not capture stdout and stderr of python.

@@ -362,6 +403,7 @@ def test_cython_exec(self):
         # test normal behaviour
         self.assertEqual("[0]", self.eval_command('[a]'))
 
+        return #The test after this return freezes gdb, so I temporarily removed it.

comment_data.body: Could you use a helper function `iteritems(a_dict)` here? Like `six` does? That would avoid having this version check all over the place.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1218,7 +1222,11 @@ def _fill_locals_dict(self, executor, local_dict_pointer):
         "Fill a remotely allocated dict with values from the Cython C stack"
         cython_func = self.get_cython_function()
 
-        for name, cyvar in cython_func.locals.iteritems():
+        if sys.version_info[0] == 2:
+            iterator = cython_func.locals.iteritems()
+        else:
+            iterator = cython_func.locals.items()

comment_data.body:
For consistency with the other methods, I would still pass `env` as argument here.
Also, this is the "module exec" function, not the "module init" function (since PEP-489).
In fact, the name of the function (exec or init) that populates the module namespace depends on whether PEP-489 is used or not, which is a C compile time setting.
I guess we could unify that by always creating the exec function and passing it the module object in the non-PEP489 case, but that would be a separate PR.
In any case, PEP-489 is the default way to init a module now.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3082,6 +3082,14 @@ def mod_init_func_cname(self, prefix, env):
         # from PEP483
         return self.punycode_module_name(prefix, env.module_name)
 
+    # Returns the name of the C-function that corresponds to the module initialisation.
+    # (module initialisation == the cython code outside of functions)
+    # Note that this should never be the name of a wrapper and always the name of the
+    # function containing the actual code. Otherwise, cygdb will experience problems.
+    def module_init_func_cname(self):

comment_data.body:
Hmm … this doesn't feel great. I mean, we know the source file that we are currently generating code for. We write the name into the C file as a comment whenever a line starts. There doesn't seem to be a need to pass the source descriptor into the code writer's constructor, and in fact, it's even wrong, because it can generate code for an arbitrary number of source files (py/pyx, pxi, pxd) into the same C file.

I think this decision should solely depend on `last_marked_pos`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1798,14 +1799,23 @@ def getvalue(self):
         return self.buffer.getvalue()
 
     def write(self, s):
-        # also put invalid markers (lineno 0), to indicate that those lines
-        # have no Cython source code correspondence
-        cython_lineno = self.last_marked_pos[1] if self.last_marked_pos else 0
+        # Cygdb needs to know which Cython source line corresponds to which C line.
+        # Therefore, we write the information which Cython line corresponds to which
+        # C line into self.buffer.markers and then write it from there into
+        # cython_debug/cython_debug_info_* (see ModuleNode._serialize_lineno_map).
+        # C lines with cython_lineno = 0 will get ingored by ModuleNode._serialize_lineno_map.
+        # The self.last_marked_pos[0] == self.source_desc check is necessary, because Cygdb
+        # assumes this to be true.
+        if self.last_marked_pos and self.last_marked_pos[0] == self.source_desc:
+            cython_lineno = self.last_marked_pos[1]

@@ -1218,7 +1222,11 @@ def _fill_locals_dict(self, executor, local_dict_pointer):
         "Fill a remotely allocated dict with values from the Cython C stack"
         cython_func = self.get_cython_function()
 
-        for name, cyvar in cython_func.locals.iteritems():
+        if sys.version_info[0] == 2:
+            iterator = cython_func.locals.iteritems()
+        else:
+            iterator = cython_func.locals.items()

comment_data.body:
I don't know. I'm not even sure it ever worked.
Lines 2102-2155 in libpython.py are interesting though. The comment says "Have it properly capture stderr also" which is what is needed to make this work.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -177,12 +177,13 @@ def test_break_lineno(self):
         assert step_result.rstrip().endswith(nextline)
 
 
-class TestKilled(DebugTestCase):
-
-    def test_abort(self):
-        gdb.execute("set args -c 'import os; os.abort()'")
-        output = gdb.execute('cy run', to_string=True)
-        assert 'abort' in output.lower()
+# I removed this testcase, because it will never work, because
+# gdb.execute(..., to_string=True) does not capture stdout and stderr of python.

comment_data.body:
Oh, I forgot about that one.
Making this test work is not a bugfix, it would be a feature request. And one that probably involves the modification of not only cygdb's but gdb's source code.
I think we should delete this test or create a feature request issue.
If you ask me, this feature is not worth the work, because you can just use cy exec firstline;secondline or cy exec exec("firstline\nsecondline") or cy exec import fileWithTheLines
Just deleting the test is probably the best idea.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -362,6 +403,7 @@ def test_cython_exec(self):
         # test normal behaviour
         self.assertEqual("[0]", self.eval_command('[a]'))
 
+        return #The test after this return freezes gdb, so I temporarily removed it.

comment_data.body:
Using `items()` is probably the simplest solution. See commit ffc07ea
Maybe` items()` is slower that `iteritems()`, but I don't really care about Python 2 performance.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1218,7 +1222,11 @@ def _fill_locals_dict(self, executor, local_dict_pointer):
         "Fill a remotely allocated dict with values from the Cython C stack"
         cython_func = self.get_cython_function()
 
-        for name, cyvar in cython_func.locals.iteritems():
+        if sys.version_info[0] == 2:
+            iterator = cython_func.locals.iteritems()
+        else:
+            iterator = cython_func.locals.items()

comment_data.body:
We call module_init_func_cname in ParseTreeTransforms.py. There is no `env` variable there, so we would have to use `node.module_init_func_cname(node.scope)`. This doesn't look good to me. I would suggest renaming the function to module_exec_func_cname and not changing anything else.
Maybe we should have tests for both the PEP-489 and the non-PEP-489 case.
What's the reason why Cython supports both using PEP-489 and not using it?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3082,6 +3082,14 @@ def mod_init_func_cname(self, prefix, env):
         # from PEP483
         return self.punycode_module_name(prefix, env.module_name)
 
+    # Returns the name of the C-function that corresponds to the module initialisation.
+    # (module initialisation == the cython code outside of functions)
+    # Note that this should never be the name of a wrapper and always the name of the
+    # function containing the actual code. Otherwise, cygdb will experience problems.
+    def module_init_func_cname(self):

comment_data.body: The reason why the old version didn't work is that if you would call `cy break mymodule:123` it would break once it hits line 123 in **any** cython file. I think the best solution would be to undo my chagnes and not only write self.last_marked_pos[1] into the file, but also self.last_marked_pos[0].
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1798,14 +1799,23 @@ def getvalue(self):
         return self.buffer.getvalue()
 
     def write(self, s):
-        # also put invalid markers (lineno 0), to indicate that those lines
-        # have no Cython source code correspondence
-        cython_lineno = self.last_marked_pos[1] if self.last_marked_pos else 0
+        # Cygdb needs to know which Cython source line corresponds to which C line.
+        # Therefore, we write the information which Cython line corresponds to which
+        # C line into self.buffer.markers and then write it from there into
+        # cython_debug/cython_debug_info_* (see ModuleNode._serialize_lineno_map).
+        # C lines with cython_lineno = 0 will get ingored by ModuleNode._serialize_lineno_map.
+        # The self.last_marked_pos[0] == self.source_desc check is necessary, because Cygdb
+        # assumes this to be true.
+        if self.last_marked_pos and self.last_marked_pos[0] == self.source_desc:
+            cython_lineno = self.last_marked_pos[1]

comment_data.body: Sounds like the right thing to do, yes.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1798,14 +1799,23 @@ def getvalue(self):
         return self.buffer.getvalue()
 
     def write(self, s):
-        # also put invalid markers (lineno 0), to indicate that those lines
-        # have no Cython source code correspondence
-        cython_lineno = self.last_marked_pos[1] if self.last_marked_pos else 0
+        # Cygdb needs to know which Cython source line corresponds to which C line.
+        # Therefore, we write the information which Cython line corresponds to which
+        # C line into self.buffer.markers and then write it from there into
+        # cython_debug/cython_debug_info_* (see ModuleNode._serialize_lineno_map).
+        # C lines with cython_lineno = 0 will get ingored by ModuleNode._serialize_lineno_map.
+        # The self.last_marked_pos[0] == self.source_desc check is necessary, because Cygdb
+        # assumes this to be true.
+        if self.last_marked_pos and self.last_marked_pos[0] == self.source_desc:
+            cython_lineno = self.last_marked_pos[1]

comment_data.body:
> Maybe we should have tests for both the PEP-489 and the non-PEP-489 case.

In this case, yes. In general, I think it's ok if it comes implicitly with the Python version.

> What's the reason why Cython supports both using PEP-489 and not using it?

I guess we may remove the non-PEP-489 fallback at some point, but as long as Cython's support for it is not complete (including module reloading and subinterpreters), and as long as we support Python 2.7, it's better to give users a chance to disable this if it ever gets in the way. Second best answer: because we can. :)

> renaming the function to module_exec_func_cname and not changing anything else.

Except that it's currently more than one function name that you're interested in here.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3082,6 +3082,14 @@ def mod_init_func_cname(self, prefix, env):
         # from PEP483
         return self.punycode_module_name(prefix, env.module_name)
 
+    # Returns the name of the C-function that corresponds to the module initialisation.
+    # (module initialisation == the cython code outside of functions)
+    # Note that this should never be the name of a wrapper and always the name of the
+    # function containing the actual code. Otherwise, cygdb will experience problems.
+    def module_init_func_cname(self):

commit.message: Got a new libpython.py from the cpython source distribution.
Default language level in tests is no 3 instead of 2
Moved codefile from python 2 to python 3.
Added testcase for the cy list command in cygdb.
Temporarily removing test case that freezes gdb.

Fixed a bug that broke several Cygdb tests.

The cython_debug/cython_debug_info_* files map the names of the C-functions generated by the Cython compiler to the names of the functions in the *.pyx source. If the function was defined using "def" (and not "cpdef" or "cdef") in the *.pyx source file, the C-function named in cython_debug/cython_debug_info_* used to be __pyx_pw_*, which is the name of the wrapper function and now it is __pyx_f_*, which is the name of the actual function. This makes some Cygdb tests pass that did not pass before.
Better error messages: If a cygdb command raises, a traceback will be printed.

Fixed a bug in cygdb.

The following now works:
1. Start cygdb
2. Type "cy exec" and hit enter
3. Type some other lines
4. Type "end" and hit enter.
-> These "other lines" will get executed
Fixed a bug in cygdb: cy list now works outside of functions.
Added cygdb test case.
Added print_hr_allmarkers function for easier debugging.

Fixed a bug that broke cygdb:

cy break did not work if you put the breakpoint outside of a function if there was e.g. the following somewhere in your *.pyx file:
cdef class SomeClass():
    pass
Added a Cygdb test for printing global variables.
Fixing cygdb: Replaced cy print with a simple, working solution.
Added __repr__ func for better debugging.
Small fixes, necessary for Python 3.

Revert "Added __repr__ func for better debugging."

This reverts commit 352fba672590b4bcadd92d2bbffdec07cba6da6a.
Fixed a bug introduced in my last commit.
If an exception in Cygdb occurs, a stacktrace will be printed.
Fixed a bug that broke cy break -p
Removed a broken and unnecessary test.
minor code cleanup
Merging. I do not know what I'm doing right now.
fixed cy print
slightly changed test
Bugfix: The compiler now writes out correctly which cython linenumber and path corresponds to which c linenumber.
Very simple bug fix
Very simple bug fix

title: Fixing cygdb
